channel.title: RNZ New Zealand Headlines
channel.description: The Latest New Zealand headlines from RNZ News

item.title: Volunteer firefighter association CEO investigated over sexual harassment and bullying complaints
item.description: The chief executive of the volunteer firefighters' association is the subject of an independent investigation relating to two complaints of sexual harassment and bullying.

item.title: Widow describes legal fight as 'David and Goliath' battle
item.description: A woman whose husband was killed in a heli-skiing crash six years ago says her long fight through the justice system felt like a "David and Goliath" battle.

item.title: Live Covid-19 updates from New Zealand and around the world on 1 September
item.description: The World Health Organisation warns emergency authorisation of Covid-19 vaccines needs great care, and coronavirus cases in the US pass 6 million.

item.title: Snow falls almost to the coast in parts of South Island
item.description: After days of warm weather parts of the South Island woke to snow today with even coastal areas getting a smattering on the first day of spring.

item.title: 'We shouldn't have to live like this': Mataura resident on third toxic waste scare
item.description: Some residents of the Southland town have bags packed ready to evacuate in case potentially lethal ammonia gas is released from toxic waste stored there.

item.title: Unprecedented increase in beneficiaries - MSD report
item.description: The number of beneficiaries rose by 12 percent in April this year, the highest increase ever in the past 24 years, and nearly double the next biggest increase.

item.title: Huge burning glow in the sky at uncontrolled fire near Aoraki/Mt Cook
item.description: Firefighters are still battling to slow a huge scrub fire burning since Sunday in Mackenzie Country, but bad weather overnight has helped their efforts.

item.title: Hipkins urges Auckland parents to send kids back to school
item.description: The Education Minister has issued a plea for all Auckland parents to send their children back to school, after thousands opted to stay away from classrooms today.

item.title: Covid-19: What happened in New Zealand on 31 August
item.description: Aucklanders enjoyed more freedoms with a drop in alert level, many businesses welcomed freedom to trade, and new rules came into play requiring all public transport users to wear masks.

item.title: Acts of charity in the alert level 3 lockdown
item.description: Meet the Shah Satnamji Green S Welfare Force as they undertake one of their community services - donating blood and plasma - in the latest instalment of Voices.

item.title: Queenstown welcomes Aucklanders for Winter Pride fest
item.description: Queenstown is in the midst of Winter Pride festival and is welcoming an influx of Aucklanders making the most of their new travel freedoms.

item.title: Fiordland tourism campaign to lure locals' friends and family
item.description: Fiordland locals are being encouraged to help stimulate the visitor economy by inviting family and friends to visit.

item.title: Megan Woods on EQC: 'Needle not moving' on botched re-repairs
item.description: Some 10 years after the first of the Christchurch earthquakes, cases of botched quake repairs needing a fix are still flooding into EQC, Greater Christchurch Regeneration minister Megan Woods says.

item.title: Aucklanders head to back to work with new mask rules
item.description: Checkpoint - Aucklanders cautiously made their way back to school and work today as the city returned to something resembling normality.

item.title: Fire at disused Mataura paper mill storing potentially toxic waste extinguished
item.description: A fire has at the former Paper Mill building in Mataura, where toxic aluminium waste is stored, has been put out.

item.title: Covid-19: Review ordered into testing order blunder
item.description: The Ministry of Health has launched a review into the blunder which saw hundred of thousands of Aucklanders wrongly told to get a Covid-19 test.

item.title: Union calls for end to 12 hour port worker shifts after death
item.description: A Maritime union is calling for an independent review and an end to 12 hour graveyard shifts after a stevedore died at Ports of Auckland this weekend.

item.title: Face mask compliance high on public transport as mandatory rules take effect
item.description: The message to mask up seems to have been well received in Wellington and Auckland today, with reports of high compliance across all forms of public transport.
